quiz.title: Algebra 2: Unit 10 Quiz 2
quiz.subtitle: 10.2: Normal Distributions and the Empirical Rule
quiz.subject: Mathematics
quiz.topic: Understanding the properties of the bell curve and the 68-95-99.7 rule

questions.question: In a normal distribution, what percentage of the data falls within one standard deviation of the mean $(\mu \pm 1\sigma)$?
questions.explanation: According to the Empirical Rule, approximately 68% of the data in a normal distribution lies within one standard deviation of the mean.

questions.question: The weights of newborn babies at a hospital are normally distributed with a mean of $7.5$ pounds and a standard deviation of $0.5$ pounds. What range of weights contains 95% of the newborns?
questions.explanation: 95% of the data falls within $2$ standard deviations. Range: $7.5 \pm 2(0.5) = 7.5 \pm 1.0$, which is $6.5$ to $8.5$ pounds.

questions.question: A set of data points has a mean of 150 and a standard deviation of 20. If the distribution is normal, what is the probability that a value is greater than 190?
questions.explanation: 190 is exactly $2$ standard deviations above the mean ($150 + 2 \times 20$). Since 95% is within $2$ deviations, 5% is outside. Because the curve is symmetric, half of that (2.5%) is in the upper tail.

questions.question: If a normal distribution has a mean of $50$ and $99.7\%$ of the data is between $20$ and $80$, what is the standard deviation ($\sigma$)?
questions.explanation: The 99.7% marker represents $3$ standard deviations. The distance from the mean ($50$) to the edge ($80$) is $30$. Therefore, $3\sigma = 30$, so $\sigma = 10$.

questions.question: Which property is NOT a characteristic of a normal distribution?
options: The distribution is skewed to the right
The mean, median, and mode are equal
The total area under the curve is 1
The curve is bell-shaped and symmetric
questions.explanation: A normal distribution is perfectly symmetric, not skewed. Skewed distributions are not 'normal'.

questions.question: In a normal distribution with mean $\mu$ and standard deviation $\sigma$, what percentage of the data lies between $\mu$ and $\mu + 1\sigma$?
questions.explanation: Since 68% lies within $1\sigma$ of the mean on both sides, and the curve is symmetric, exactly half of that (34%) lies between the mean and one standard deviation above it.

questions.question: A test score distribution is normal with $\mu = 75$ and $\sigma = 10$. Approximately what percentage of scores fall between $65$ and $85$?
questions.explanation: The range $65$ to $85$ is $\mu - 1\sigma$ to $\mu + 1\sigma$. By the Empirical Rule, this accounts for 68% of the data.

questions.question: A set of measurements has $\mu = 1,200$ and $\sigma = 100$. What percentage of the data falls between $1,100$ and $1,400$?
A machine fills containers with a mean of $20$ oz and a standard deviation of $0.05$ oz. If the distribution is normal, what percentage of containers have less than $19.95$ oz?
questions.explanation: $19.95$ oz is exactly one standard deviation below the mean. Since 68% is within $\pm 1\sigma$, 32% is outside. Half of that (16%) is in the lower tail.

questions.question: True or False: In any normal distribution, the area to the left of the mean is always $0.5$.
questions.explanation: True. Symmetry dictates that exactly 50% of the total area (which is 1) lies on each side of the mean.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You've mastered the Empirical Rule.
scoreMessages.70: Good job. Try drawing the bell curve to visualize the percentages.
scoreMessages.0: Review the Empirical Rule and the symmetry of the normal curve.
